awd_abstract_narration:
The ability of systems to assemble and organize without direct control or intervention is fundamental to biological and non-biological systems. Materials such as complex polymers may self-assemble into a wide variety of forms, and have many nanotechnology and biomedical applications. This project studies models of material self-assembly to develop theoretical insight and predictive capabilities. Formulas are developed that connect microscopic molecular properties to mechanical and morphological behaviors at larger scales. Computations are employed for predicting novel behaviors and custom-tailoring inputs for engineered nanostructures. The award provides research and educational opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students.

This project broadly investigates polymer, amphiphilic, and particle-based systems, and processes fundamental to the creation of nanoscale materials. Models describing formation of nanoparticles and amphiphilic structures in heterogeneous polymer systems are examined using a mixture of analytical and computational approaches that quantify equilibria, morphology, and dynamics. In conjunction with these models, algorithms for inverse problems will be developed for purposes of parameter identification and engineering design. Self-assembled systems involving a large number of interacting particles are studied within the same framework, leading to predictions of pattern formation and collective behavior. Byproducts of the research include the development of numerical and inverse problem algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Arizona Board of Regents, University of Arizona

por.por_cntn:
This award funded three distinct subprojects, with a common thread of applying mathematical and computational techniques to models in materials science.


The first subproject studied amphiphilic structures, materials composed of two-component molecules in which components have opposite affinities for the surrounding solvent (such as water).  These occur organically, as in biological membranes, or can be synthesized from block copolymers.  Geometrically, amphiphiles form spherical, cylindrical, and extended sheet-like domains, whose form depends on molecular composition and dynamics.  We have developed a complete theory which connects basic molecular parameters to the expected geometric configurations,and have shown that this theory correlates well with experimental observations. This allows for customization of synthetic molecules and enables engineering of nanostructured amphiphiles useful in biotechnology applications.


Modeling in materials science is rarely derived from basic scientific principles alone, which means that blending fundamental physics and observations can produce more reliable descriptions. A second project initiative developed data-driven algorithms that can determine constitutive aspects of mathematical models even in cases where there is only partial knowledge of the system.  Our discovery algorithms successfully recovered well known equations of pattern forming material systems, using only observation snapshots as input.  They were also show to be robust in the presence of highly noisy data, and can even learn model equations from scratch without needing any physical principles at all.  These algorithms simultaneously infer missing data, and can therefore also be used for reconstruction of noisy or incomplete data, such as images of microstructure or flow patterns.

The third subproject focused on developing particle-based descriptions that reproduce phenomenon characteristically described by complicated differential equations.  The explicit connection between these different paradigms was demonstrated mathematically as well as through numerical simulation.  Particle models offer a far simplified view of complex systems, enabling efficient computational methods and the ability to study and engineer large-scale complex systems.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2024
Modified by: Karl B Glasner
